text: Rivers, teeming with microscopic life thread like spaghetti through a geography of living cells.  Invaders. Territory is overrun.  The view is like an aerial recon photo of an alien land -- at war.
Rivers, gleaming in the sun, thread like spaghetti throug a geography of jungle terrain, perfectly matching the patterns of the virus landscape.
A Fokker light air transport descends into view.

As the transport busses overhead, AFRICAN GREEN MONKEYS, hundreds of them, frolic and chatter in the trees. A BIG MALE watches inquisitive.  The plane's SHADOW passe over him.  The Male opens its mouth frighteningly wide; a "threat display."  Four HUGE FANGS flash at the intruder.
Twenty five feet above the Ebola River.
The Transport touches down and stops on the empty field.

A Land Rover emerges.  Then another.  "WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION" emblems on the side panels.  We see a SIX PERSON MULTINATIONAL EPIDEMIC TEAM inside. Hermetically sealed hospital isolator stretchers with its own air supply sticks out the back of each.  A casualty inside can't infect the world outside.
We see the Rovers speeding into the bush.  Cargo doors close.  Engines rev.
Picking up speed.
The plane BARELY CLEARS the trees sending Green Monkeys scattering in all directions.  Their angry cries echo;

A handful of ZAIREAN POLICE guard the primitive landing. REFUGEE VILLAGERS camp along the banks in the b.g. One POLICEMAN passes out half-cooked monkey. The POLICE CAPTAIN chews on a bloody haunch, licking his fingers.  The Ferry Bell RINGS O.S. Now a jeep HORN HONKS O.S. approaching --

The primitive Ferry parts the mist.  Four wooden canoes held together by a plank deck.  FERRYMEN buck the current with long poles. KARL JOHNSON EMERGES from the mist.  He stands on the hoo of the lead Rover WEARING A FULL FACE RESPIRATOR.  A creature from another planet.
CHUCK REESE (22) honks at the wheel.  He wears a full respirator.  All the team members wear respirators.
(in French)
Do not shoot.  Do not shoot. American Doctor!  Doctor!
He raises his respirator staring right into the guns -- A 30, he's already a legendary field virologist. He surveys the scene like a military general as the Ferry lands.
(in French)

Johnson.  Center for Disease Control. U.S.A. -- We're headed to the Yambuku Mission. He points to his armband; CDC shield -- U.S. flag. Police respond yelling threats at the frightened Ferrymen and banging their weapons on the Rovers.
He is about to soil his trousers.  The two Norwegian Team members whisper in their language.
Jesus Christ, these people should be quarantined.  This outbreak is outta control --
Meager belongings, hungry children, terrified.
(in French)
How far to Yambuku? Silence.  The Police Captain approaches menacingly.
(in French)

You don't want to go there, Doctor. There is nothing but death there. People are dying all along the river -- SISTER GENEVIEVE, a Belgian Catholic Nurse, approaches from the Refugee camp.  40's, haggard, suffering dehydration.  She pushes past the Police, unafraid.
(in French)
Etes-vous Doctor Johnson? (in English)
-- I am Sister Genevieve from the Yambuku Mission -- Johnson offers a bottle of Perrier -- Sister chugs it.
Bless you, Doctor --
Save the blessings, Sister -- He signals to Reese.

Reese, get the Sister some salt tablets and a shot of B12.  She's dehydrating. Petrified, Reese breaks out the medical kit from the Rover.  A Policeman tracks his every move at gunpoint. He is so nervous he fumbles the salt tablets and vitamins dropping them.  Sister politely pushes the guns aside and helps him pick them up. Johnson watches her.  He's impressed by her courage.

Tell our hosts I need blood samples -- Sister, tissue samples -- before this bug burns itself out.  I have to get to Yambuku.  If I can find one survivor, then We, not God, can maybe cure this thing. The Captain separates them.  He sticks his gun in Johnson's crotch.  He understands English perfectly --
(in English)
Do not be coming back this way, Doctor.  Quarantine -- (pointing to the jungle)
We will shoot you if you try. Johnson tosses packs of cigarettes to the Police defiantl and climbs back in the Rover.
You are certifiable, Dr. -- Suddenly, Sister Genevieve straightens her habit and jump in.
I shall guide you to Yambuku, Doctor. Johnson starts to protest.  He sees her conviction.
Bless You, Sister. THE VIEW CLIMBS as the Rover speeds off the landing and disappears into the bush.
Sitting vigil crouched outside a hut.  Eyes fixed -- unwavering.  WE HEAR:  Horrible sounds of suffering inside.

Huts burn and smolder.  Termite ant hills tower over some of the remains.  A handful of BANTU watch the old Elder. The Women wails a death chant. A HAND reaches out the doorway to bowls of food and water Suddenly, it clenches in agony.  Blood hemorrhages throug pulpy skin.  The hand flops to the dirt. The Elder rises in silence.  Torch in hand, he chants a prayer and torches the hut. A BANTU WOMAN screams rushing towards her flaming home. OTHER WOMEN pull her back. The Elder picks up his medicine bundle and leads the survivors of his Village into the Bush.
Johnson signals to go slower.  Reese is riveted to his window.  Burned devastation everywhere.  Sister prays.
Smoldering in the ruins.  Reese is sickened.
My God, what happened here?

The Bantu.  They've gone back to their ancient ways of dealing with plague and malaria.  You put the sick person in a hut.  You put food and water in the door.  If the person walks out one day -- or crawls out, that's fine.  If they don't... you burn the hut... No more disease --
Two Team Members crank photographs.
The Rovers stop nearby.  Sister Genevieve, exhausted, rests her head on the seat. Johnson climbs out surveying the sight.  This is his war.
This whole zone is hot.  Reese. He kicks at the hut's burning embers.
Whatever this bug is, Ebola is not a place we're gonna forget anytime soon -- He turns to:  REESE, who is frantically removing his gear from the lead Rover.  He shoots Karl a frightened glance.

I'm not going upcountry, Doc.  I'm taking my team out -- We'll base at the hospital in Kinshasa -- Reese passes Johnson heading for the other Rover.  The Team reacts confused as he plops his gear inside.
You're a good doctor.  They need your services too.  Couple of things you might consider -- Reese doesn't want to hear it.
Maybe we've already been exposed. As Karl speaks, he ties off his own arm, thumps a vein an draws his own blood.
Test all our blood when you get back.  Take some samples from Sister Genevieve:  here too --
Sweat beads on her forehead under her habit.  Her vision BLURS for a millisecond then corrects itself.  She watche Johnson confront Reese without ever raising his voice.
Maybe this bug can spread through the air.  Maybe it's the Andromeda Strain -- Johnson tosses the blood vial --
He stares at the blood vial like death itself.
If it is Andromeda, then you won't be safe anywhere in the world. The Team audibly reacts in French and Norwegian.  Winds kick up smoke swirling around Johnson.
You might as well be here at the epicenter trying to stop it.
The lone Rover travels slowly along the rough road.  In the f.g., GREEN MONKEYS FOLLOW, jumping from limb to branch, escorting Johnson deeper into the jungle.
The infection hit the hospital like a -- like a bomb --
Who was the index case?  The first patient to "show"?

A Schoolteacher.  We treated him for malaria -- Two days later, he died -- horribly.  Every child at the school came to the hospital. Families -- pregnant women.  All broke with fever. Johnson traces the spread in his mind, sorting, seeking -
But where did the teacher get the bug?  Rodent bites? -- Feces? Mosquitoes?  Monkeys maybe? Sister Genevieve shakes her head bewildered.  Who knows?
How did it spread so quickly?  What did you give the patients?
Injections.  Chloroquine and vitamins.  These people do not believe they have been "doctored" unless we give them a shot... She hesitates, almost confessing.
We only used five syringes a day to treat everyone --
(grim diagnosis)
Then the infection could've been passed through the needles --
God forgive us... Some became irrational -- hostile -- and escaped!  Hundreds became violently ill and died in one week -- Silence.  Johnson realizes he's facing nature's revenge.

Seven days.  No time for an "immune response."  By the time the patient's immune system throws antibodies to fight the damn thing -- it's too late... She breaks down, sobbing.  Johnson stops the Rover.
You did what you could, Sister. He takes her hands in his, firmly but gently.  He's wearing surgical gloves.

The Yambuku Mission.  An imposing old chapel and a ring o cinderblock buildings.  The Belgian flag hangs at half- mast in the center.  No life anywhere -- Suddenly, a FOUR FOOT TALL MALE GREEN MONKEY drops on the hood from the trees with full force -- screeching at them Sister screams with fright.  Johnson jumps so much he bumps his head on the ceiling.
Swarm the Rover on a food search, screeching "KRA, KRA."
One Monkey lands on the door latch.  It's weight pulls th Sister's door open.  She cries out. JOHNSON FALLS across her closing it tight.
Flashes his fangs and hurls his feces, splattering agains the windshield.  Then he is gone.
Open air porches are lined with empty beds.  Silence. Only the chattering of the monkeys in the trees.
He now wears a Tyvek protective suit, boots and full face respirator.  He carries a field kit and a small ice chest
Flies buzz swarming out the windows and doors.
Johnson opens the door.  Light spills in.  Flies swarm. Their buzzing sounds like chainsaws.
A silhouette of tangled bodies.  The mud walls are splattered with blood -- as if a bomb did go off.
Don't come in here, Sister.
Sinks slowly to her knees, frozen like a statue, praying.
Down the rows of 120 beds, inspecting the few remaining bodies, each with evidence of massive hemorrhaging from every orifice.

He stops at one bed, carefully checking a YOUNG MAN for signs of life.  He feels for a pulse -- His glove fingers sink into the man's flesh like pudding. Johnson reels back -- reviled.  His breath labored.

Taking a nose swab blood sample.  Another swab inside the Man's mouth -- and ears.  With tweezers, he pinches out samples of skin tissues. WE FOLLOW bloody swaps and skin tissues into plastic vials.  Johnson tags and places each in the ice chest.
Numbers:  001, etc., then, "Yambuku blood and epidermal tissue slices - Ebola, Zaire."
Johnson exits, exhausted, solemn.  Sister Genevieve is still bent in prayer, motionless; wearing her respirator.
No survivors.  I've never seen a bug kill like this one, Sister. Fried by his experience, he surveys the jungle.  Surreal in the golden light.  He's completely spaced.

There must be members of some lost tribe out there who've built up immunities to this killer over the years -- Their blood could have powerful antibodies passed down through the generations... strong enough to save some lives -- (silence, he reaches her)
Sister --

Slowly raises her bowed head.  Blood oozes from her respirator.  Her faceplate is splattered with it. She collapses before he can catch her.  Johnson cradles her removing the respirator.  He's horrified.
You spiked the damn fever -- We'll get you to Kinshasa. Blood traces from her tearducts -- her nose and ears.

Oh my god -- hold on -- hold on -- He pulls a syringe from his pocket -- thumps up a vein an begins to shoot her full of antibiotics.  She reflexes away from the needle -- internal hemorrhages rock her -- Johnson jerks back.  The SYRINGE PIERCES the glove on his left hand.  He stares at it in horror.  He yanks it out sucking his hand and spitting -- like a snake bite.
First... come... the... headaches -- She spasms suddenly -- coughing up black fluid --

head_text.subj: THE VIEW ROCKETS UP UP INTO THE TREES --

text: Monkeys cry everywhere.  "KRA!  KRA!"  We rocket right into the face of the BIG GREEN MALE.  Deep brown cloudy eyes staring at us transfixed.  Blood -- building in a crimson wave -- emerges from it's nose.
A modest colonial sits atop a hill at the foot of the Appalachians.  Leaves glow in bright autumn colors. SUPER:  FREDERICK, MD - WED., OCT. 4, 1989 0800 HRS.
Jason -- you'll be late for school.

THE FREEZER DOOR CLOSES REVEALING:  COL. NANCY JAXX; a rather beautiful woman in her mid 30's.  "Supermom" and "ultrawife" in Army uniform with Colonel's bars taking he usual stab at breakfast; throwing 4 waffles in the microwave -- cracking two eggs in a skillet -- She opens cabinet, gets mugs, dumps in instant coffee -- suddenly -

head_text.subj: A MONKEY LIKE CREATURE HANGS DOWN RIGHT IN HER FACE --

text: (pushes it away, annoyed)
Jason!  Come feed Gumby or he's going in your omelette! No response.  The Kinkajoo wraps its prehensile tail around her neck.
Jaxx piggybacks the Kinkajoo and a cup of coffee through the converted sunporch.  It's filled with ANIMALS.
Two fish tanks, a fish pond, exotic Parrots, Bright Red Eclectus, Cockatoos -- and four Yellow naped Amazons.  On sings an opera aria.  One wolf whistles as Jaxx passes.
(ritual)
Thanks boys.  Eat your heart out girls -- She steps over an old bulldog in the doorway.  The dog, MAGGIE, flatulates in her sleep.  Jaxx fans the air.
Oh -- Maggie -- please -- A loose scarlet Parrot walking behind Jaxx pecks Maggie's stumpy tail instantly rousing the old dog to a barking frenzy.  The Aviary adds squawks and screeches.
She opens the door on her 13 year old son, JASON; his lanky frame all over the bed, sleeping with his Walkman.
Jason?  Wakey wakey -- She tosses the Kinkajoo through the air and closes the door, blocking the view.  WE HEAR:  Jason yell.
Jaxx heads for the converted garage passing a red Toyota pickup parked in the drive.  The magnetic sign on the doo panel reads:  "JAXX VETERINARY CLINIC."

As Jaxx enters, BLACKHAWK, their big black hunting Bouvie bounds over to greet her. 6'3" GERRY JAXX is dipping his "boarders" in a tickbath. His haircut still military sharp.  Now a civilian, his years in the army reflect in his physical fitness.
Ready for your fix -- ? Nancy offers him a cup of coffee --
Ah, Nance.  The life of a country veterinarian is sheer bliss. He's lying.  His hands are elbow deep in doggie-bath.
Aw -- You miss the Army that much? Why not Re-enlist?
Never.  Then I would have to call you, "Colonel" -- He embraces her caressing her buns.  She caresses his back.  Somebody clears their throat O.S.
Their daughter -- Twelve year old JAMIE -- bounces in her sweat clothes.  She wears braces and never stops.  Never.
(through glass doors)
There are children present.  I mean -- "Hello"?
Breaking their clinch, "caught."
Morning, Princess.
Go eat your breakfast -- or we'll be late for school --
She makes a face; a complete rebel.

In a minute -- watch me! She poises by a tree, as if beginning a floor exercise. Suddenly, the Kinkajoo leaps from a low branch landing on Jamie's head.  She jumps with a shriek. MOM AND DAD react, laughing.  Nothing dangerous here.
The Kinkajoo clings to her hair.
C'mon, Gumby.  Let's show'em. She sets the creature down beside her, preps and throws a standing back flip with an Olympic finish. The Kinkajoo does a flip too.
Gerry applauds.  Jaxx indicates "time for school."  JASON wanders in, zombied.  He holds up seared waffles.
Breakfast is burned... again. Jamie walks in on her hands.
Still eating with your hands, butthead?
Can she talk to me that way, Mom?
Let's try not to kill each other before Thanksgiving, okay?
After Thanksgiving, she's toast. (Jamie swats him)
Mom, I need money for lunch --
I got a meet Friday, Mom.  You're coming aren't cha -- ? Before Jaxx can answer, Jamie literally throws aerials ou of the clinic.
Please -- no acrobatics in the -- Jamie pays no attention.  Gerry looks at Jaxx dismayed.
She gets her stubbornness from you, Mrs. Jaxx.
I think you mean independence. She's your daughter -- Jaxx exits by a starving Jason.  Blackhawk jumps up snatching the burned waffle from his hand.
CHILDREN play in a sandbox.  A LITTLE BOY spoons up some sand and eats it.  Yukk.  He spites it all over the GIRL next to him.  Two more KIDS drink juice from the same cup

In red letters:  "PACIFIC PRIMATES - MANILA, PHILIPPINES. Green Monkeys peer out from partition openings at the children.  Sniffing.  A new scent in this new land.  Some monkeys flash their fangs.  Others chatter.
Kids stare back at the monkeys with giggles and delight. The WOMEN SUPERVISOR pulls two FIGHTING CHILDREN apart. The GIRL bites the BOY on the hand -- drawing blood.

An alley separates the Day Care Center from a windowless building.  MONKEY HANDLERS unload crates from a truck. The logo on the cargo doors read:  SYNERGY RESEARCH LABS. The handlers carry the Monkey crates into the rear of the building.  TINY WHIPPERT, the strawboss, wears overalls, plaid hunting shirt, ball cap, pony tail, a deer skinning knife and weighs about 350. DEKE, a biker type and LOC, a Vietnamese who speaks no English, help Tiny transfer the monkey crates from the truck one at a time.  They wear no masks -- just gloves. All are expert monkey handlers.
I love the part when Bruce Willis grins like he just got a little you know.  He hits that detonator and yells "adios mother fuckaouch!" He dumps his end of the crate wringing his hand in pain.
Ow -- little cocksucker bit the shit -- outta me --
You're probably the little shit's first meal since it left Africa. Tiny shucks his glove and sucks his bloody finger.
Got two hundred more to go, Tiny. You need more fingers. Tiny shoots him the "bloody" finger.
HOMES.  The Monkey house is right in the middle of suburbia.  Twenty-five miles from Washington D.C.

The base spreads at the eastern slope of the Appalachian Mountains.  WE PASS OVER by an array of 90 foot radio dishes.  This is a major defense communications center. SUPER:  FT. DETRICK, MD - NOV. 16, 0900 HRS.
Vent stacks on the roof aim up at us like deck guns.
U.S.A.M.R.I.I.D.
Insiders call it "RIID" for short.
TIGHT ON USAMRIID SHIELD:  Twin serpents entwine around a flaming sword.  The slogan; "Research for the Soldier."
Jaxx enters waving to the camera. WIDEN TO:  A SECURITY GUARD sits vigil over a bank of monitors with exterior views of the entire facility; containment labs, corridors, monkey cages...
A figure in a shiny space suit peers into a microscope.

We follow Jaxx through the institutional halls.  At close double doors, she uses her security card on a necklace from inside her uniform blouse and swipes it across a black magnetic sensor on the wall.
Doors spring open.  Jaxx enters.  A sign overhead reads:
Jaxx passes by individual containment rooms with several species of Monkeys in cages.  The place is spotless.  Eas listening ROCK MUSIC plays over the PA.
Jaxx stops to watch two young WOMEN; PFC, GODWIN (17) and SGT. KLAGES (18) wearing masks, Plexiglas visors and gloves as they vaccinate a big African Green Monkey.
Jaxx enters wearing a visor mask, visor and gloves. Godwin is singing softly to the monkey.
Colonel, Jaxx --
(putting them at ease)
Good morning, Ladies -- How's "Super Monk."

Super Monk is immune to Simian Hemorrhagic and he just threw off another heavy Lassa fever challenge. Strong antibody response.  He's the healthiest primate in captivity. Super Monk scarfs down monkey biscuits, ravenous.
A MOUSE CAGE; made of popsicle sticks.  Inside are three white mice made of pipecleaners.  Each wears a tinfoil ga mask.  A fading card on the side in a child's hand reads:
A family photo sits on the cluttered desk next to it. Jaxx poses with Jamie holding a Gymnastics trophy. The phone RINGS... Again... Again.  JAXX HURRIES by the glass partition, enters and answers.
Jaxx --
The Fifty-year old Man on the phone looks worried.
(on phone)
Stan Girard -- remember?  Synergy, right.  I'm chief research Vet. We've got a little problem at one of our quarantine units not too far from you --
(on phone, taking notes)
Five hundred Greens and Macaques -- shipped from Philippines six weeks ago -- Simian Hemorrhagic fever?
He examines a dissected monkey on a "bleed table" with gloves, his mask down around his neck.
(on phone)
Necropsies on the fatalities show enlarged spleens -- some petechiae --
(on phone)
Classic symptoms for SHF.  What's the body count? (a pause, eerie feeling)
Seventy in the last week?
Narrow.  Windowless.  Lined with 100 wall mounted stainless steel cages.  Live monkeys stare listless. Ghost-like.
A Monkey tumbles into his net.  Dead. TO TINY:  hosing down the blood on the floor kicking up a aerosol mist.
We lost twenty-seven more this morning.  So far just one room is infected -- FOLLOW THE MIST:  Swirling up past monkey cages to ventilators in the ceiling --
The fine mist rolls from a ceiling vent DOWN TO:  GIRARD
(on phone)
But, well, Management doesn't want to lose the whole population -- We've got over a quarter million dollars in these monkeys --
(on phone)

I'd keep that room isolated.  We know SHF isn't lethal to people, just monkeys -- Make sure your handlers use normal contagion precautions.  Yeah, get some "B&T" samples up to us today we'll get on it.  Right -- She hangs up tentatively, then hurries out.  PUSH IN ON: The pipecleaner mice wearing gas masks.
A carpet of living cells takes on a spider web look.
Liver cells.  Monkey sample #053 -- What do you think?

Jaxx adjusts the view wearing gloves and surgical masks for Biosafety Level 3 lab. PETER JAHRLING turns the glass flask containing the cell culture under the microscope.  Late 30's, garrulous, blac heavy glasses; the quintessential lab scientist.
Looks like Simian to me.  The infected cells have a definite spider web look. He studies the magnified image on a video monitor attache to the microscope.

What's another bug in this house anyway -- ? He points through a glass partition to two industrial sized refrigerators, both with computer locks.  The RED TREFOIL symbol for "biological hazard" marks the doors like skull and crossbones.
We got enough BL4 viruses and bacteria in there to make AIDS look like a runny nose.
Hey, there's a happy thought.  I try not to think about it. (checking scope again)
Let's be sure about this bug.  Run some antigens --
Jaxx removes one labeled "ANTIBODY SERUM - SIMIAN HF." She draws a drop of the liquid in a pipette -- then inserts it into the flask. Peter flicks on the ultraviolet scope light.
Go for the gold.

Cells glow in the ultraviolet.  Suddenly, the dark antige solution clouds the view.  Antibodies surround infected cells glowing bright fluorescent golden orange. Jaxx studies the scope as Peter refers to a chart.
He scans down bar graphs of fluorescent colors to a GOLDE ORANGE BAR labeled:  "Simian Hemorrhagic Fever."
Bingo.  Positive for SHF.  Good news for us -- bad news for the monkeys. Jaxx peers into the microscope.
Hey -- there's something flaky going on in this flask --
Blackholes grow in the carpet of glowing cells as if eate by moths.  Dead and dying cells float away --
That's not like any SHF I've ever seen.  Something is blowing those cells away.  They're off the plastic. She doesn't like it.  She pulls Peter to the scope.

Aw, just some crud in the scope. Pseudomonas bacterium maybe.  Really annoying.  Wipes out everything. You have to start over.  The little suckers smell like Welches grape juice -- He takes the flask, opens it and sniffs it --
Yeah and a virus kills with no odor -- So what've you got? Peter continues to sniff.  A look of consternation.  He suddenly caps it, getting the creeps.
Nothing... No... smell.
Okay, okay -- so we've got an "unknown" here, Pete -- Jaxx flares concern.  They both stare at the flask.
Let's do it by the numbers.  How long will it take you to culture another isolate and get it on the big scope so we can see what the damn thing is?
(starts to sweat)
I'll need more monkey samples.  Ten, twelve hours maybe.  First thing in the A.M.
(heading for door)
Call your wife.  Tell her we're shacking up together.  I'm going to pump C.J. to get us some of those monkeys --
You know -- Karl Johnson could tell just by looking if this crud was Lassa, Marburg, Ebola, Anthrax -- Peter sets the flask down gingerly.  Jaxx lingers.
I was a green recruit my first year here at RIID when Johnson "retired." I don't think he ever even knew who I was.  How come you mention his name around here, everyone crawls in a hole?
(matter of fact)
Karl thinks the world's got a gun to its head and there's not a damn thing anyone can do to keep us from pulling the trigger. (a beat of respect)
That scares people in high places... He's the best bug man there is.  Why don't you ask him? Jaxx flusters.
Yeah, well, okay -- but he's not here -- We are. Jaxx exits slamming the door.  The warning sign reads:
He ponders the flask for a moment.  He pulls on his surgical mask, pours the milky fluid from it into a test tube, places the tube in a centrifuge and turns it on.
Whirls to a blur.
Staring right at us outside the Yambuku Mission.  1976. His Field Team and 2 Nuns flank him.  One of them is Sister Genevieve, alive.  With Village Children.  Smiles of hope.
Jaxx is transfixed on the photograph.  Thick files fill her desk.  She flips through more photos -- there it is.

head_text.subj: A PHOTO OF FIVE YOUNG MEN AND ONE YOUNG WOMEN

text: Stand in front of a Huey Helicopter all wearing inflated orange spacesuits with clear bubble helmets.  They flank Karl Johnson beside a biomedical isolator litter.  The caption reads:
PUSH IN ON:  the young woman -- PFC Nancy Jaxx, age 22.
She calls up a data base. ENTRY:  SEARCH FOR> JOHNSON, KARL M.
Jaxx hesitates.  She types a message quickly into the computer.

head_text.subj: PLEASE CONTACT ME AT EARLIEST CONVENIENCE

text: Peter works in the b.g.  WE MOVE IN ON THE TEST TUBE TO A MICROSCOPIC VIEW:  The geography of cells are at war.
A SHINY GYMNASTICS MEDAL is displayed in a place setting on the counter. JAXX ENTERS lugging files.  Blackhawk is there to greet her with licks and whines.
Hey, big guy.  You hungry?  So am I. She melts seeing the medal.  There's a note.  She reads:

Your amazing daughter took second. Your amazing son washed the dishes. And your amazing husband put your dinner in the microwave.  Check the machine -- Nancy chuckles.  While the machine rewinds, she opens a cabinet and pulls down a can of dog food.  The electric can opener doesn't work.

Nance, Girard just called.  Seven more monkeys kicked.  They've got them on ice.  Meet C.J. there at 0800.  This guy Girard sounds spooked. She rifles the drawer.  No opener.  She uses a beer opene punching around the edge.  The lid bends in -- Her hand slips into the can -- slicing on the jagged edge She holds her fist in pain checking the damage.  Nothing. Then blood leeches from the clean cut on her right hand.
Jaxx twines a wide Band-aid over her wound and closes the medicine cabinet.  She jumps with fright at THE FACE leering right behind her --
Jamie -- oh -- hon -- Jamie is half asleep -- still in her gym suit.
(drowsy)
I didn't get first, Mom --
Mother and daughter enter arms around each other.

We're proud of you even if you don't win.  I'm just sorry I had to miss your big moment -- Jamie falls into bed.  Jaxx pulls off her warmups by the pant legs.  Then the jacket.  She drifts off.  Jaxx kisse Jamie goodnight.
The CAMERA ROCKETS along the cages right up to the last monkey.  Death stare.  A single stream of blood trickles from it's nose.
Kids head for school in packs.  CRANE DOWN TO:
Jason and Jamie exit heading for school.  Jaxx takes her daughter's hand.  Jamie squeezes back.
(ritual)
"be nice to mice," Mom.  Promise. Remember, "all animals --
"All animals are our brothers and sisters." (polite parental tolerance)
I know -- I know, Princess.  Do good, you two -- Love you! Jaxx watches them head for school.  It's a Mom's life.
Kids romp in the play-yard at the day care center. SUPER:  RESTON, VA. - WEDNESDAY, NOV. 17 - 0830 HRS. Jaxx's car is parked behind the station down the alley. She watches the kids from the payphone.
(on phone)
Any results yet?
He's dragging from no sleep.  He spins another test tube in the centrifuge.
(on phone)
We've got zip and I'm about out of monkey parts.
(on phone)
We're working on it.
Kids eat mud-pies.  PAN TO:  The funky rear door to the monkey house.  Empty monkey crates are stacked in back.
(on phone)
Any messages?  I was expecting a fax --
Nada.  Guess nobody loves you.
(on phone)
Thanks, Pete.  I needed that.
Heading up the alley her way.  He's pissed.  Forty. Thinning hair.  Bulging middle in his Army uniform. Deputy Commander of "RIID."  Brilliant virologist with a grim sense of humor.
Where's your happy face, C.J.?
(sardonic grin)
Girard's not going to let us in. He's afraid our army uniforms will "upset his staff."  Mercy --
I don't like this, C.J.  Day-care center -- little kids --
Just worry about the monkeys. Girard said Management's already on him about calling in the Army.  Tell you one thing, whatever's going on in there, he's scared.  They're bringing the samples here.
Oh, free home delivery.  Nice.
Heads up the alley and stops beside them.  TINY WHIPPERT leans from the cab.  Big toothy grin.
Hi.  How you, M'am?  Uh, General M'am -- ? Jaxx smiles putting the nervous Tiny at ease.
Col. Jaxx and this is Col. Peters Deputy Commander at RIID. Tiny shyly lumbers out revealing Deer Rifles in a rack behind his seat.  He ambles to the back, nursing coffee talking a bluestreak.
We got dead "cynos" ever day.  Y'all think y'all can find out what's killin'em, huh?
Tiny opens the door.  Jaxx and C.J. gawk at 7 plastic garbage bags.  No one wants to be the first to grab one.
"Samples?" You brought whole monkeys?  Are they disinfected and triple bagged?
You bet.  Wouldn't want to get any on ya -- Jaxx is appalled.
These Cynos all came from Room F?
Nope.  Room H. Jaxx and C.J. trade concerned glances.
It's jumped to a new room.  Do all the monkeys breathe the same air?
Guess so.  If a monkey even farts in one room, you can smell it in another.  No offense M'am -- Jaxx pulls C.J. behind her car.  Both unnerved.
We've got a possible aerosol contaminant here -- and we know it's not Simian Fever.

But -- it's lethal.  I'm a Veterinarian.  I can't knowingly transport a dead animal with an infectious disease across state lines without a permit.  I can lose my license.  No way it's going to stay quiet we transported them. You're a Doc.  You can plead ignorance. She thumps his big gold lapel bars --
This -- is why you get to wear those big eagles, Colonel, Sir --
And -- your car's shittier than mine. Jaxx bats her green eyes over the top "Miss Scarlett." C.J. starts to protest.  What's the use.
The monkey's weight depresses the rear end of his car. C.J. slams the lid.  It won't shut.  He and Tiny sit on it.  It closes with a sickening crunch.
Sweating profusely.  He squeezes a pain between his eyes.
Tiny waves.  Suddenly, Jaxx and C.J. BLUR in Tiny's vision.  He rubs his eyes.  His vision clears.
Need anymore, just holler.  Have a good one now, ya hear? C.J. waves morbidly as the VAN WIPES FRAME TO:
I better follow you.  Make sure you don't... drip.
C.J. bottoms out on a bump exiting the drive.  Sparks fly
She whiteknuckles her steering wheel waiting for his trun to pop open.  It holds.
As they pass by, a LITTLE BOY STANDS on top of the slide pounding his chest like King Kong -- making monkey faces. Kids run around scared and screeching.
Jaxx hurries in and checks her message box.  She rifles them quickly.  No Johnson.  Damn --
Jaxx swipes her security card over the sensor.  Pneumatic gaskets HISS retreating around the submarine style airloc door.  Jaxx hurries in.  The door seals shut behind her.

head_text.subj: VIRUS, EBOLA VIRUS, MANTAAN VIRUS, CRIMEAN-CONGO

text: Jaxx enters the staging area pulling on her scrubs and surgical cap.  The RED LIGHT glows over the BL4 airlock door.  She dials a wall phone.
(on phone)
Pete -- I'm going hotside.  Any last requests --
He's running on fumes.
Yeah, a monkey TV dinner.  We're striking out here.  Big zero. He mounts a button of cells on a slicer.  A diamond knife peels off a tiny slice.  He captures it on a tiny mesh.

She opens a cabinet door.  Ultraviolet floods.  She pulls out a Blue spacesuit.  One piece, soft helmet, thick rubber gloves and foot molds -- like feet pajamas. She slides her right hand into a surgical glove.  The Band-aid over her cut hand is intact.  She then tapes the glove to her sleeve with brown sticky tape. Next she slides her gloved hands down the spacesuit sleeves into the heavier surgical gloves.
A metal tower eight feet tall.  Peter places the cell slice in the chamber of the big scope.

Closing her diagonal zipper, then the airtight Ziploc. She heads into a stainless-steel multiheaded "envirochem" shower.  WE HEAR:  BREATHING.  Now her HEART BEAT, steady rhythmic.  Her faceplate fogs up.
ON THE VIEWING SCREEN:  a cellscape appears.  Oxbow river and lakes like an aerial view of a jungle.  We've seen this view before.  An ominous sight --
Coiled airhoses hang from the ceiling like spaghetti. Jaxx grabs one -- and hooks it into the short hose protruding from a "MEPA" filter canister on her thigh.
A rush of air ROARS like a freight train.  Her faceplate clears.  She moves to a "pass through chute," opens it -- She pulls a monkey bag through onto a stainless steel bleed table.
He scans the cellscape, like flying.  Searching.  He abruptly stops.  He stares in horror at the screen.
So thick with virus it looks like buckets of rope.
Oh shit... oh... shit... Peter holds up a cellscape micrograph next to the viewing screen.  The picture is labeled:  EBOLA, ZAIRE; LUNG SLIC PATIENT 17, 1976.  It's loaded with the same virus.

Her gloved hand picks up a scalpel from the "sharps" box. She makes the chest incision O.S.  She raises her gloves back into view -- both are dripping with blood. She dunks both in the Clorox pan, cleaning them.
Peter enters the suite from the shower in his spacesuit. He's distraught, carrying micrographs.
Jaxx -- We got a problem -- No response.  He forgot his headset!  Sweat runs down his nose.  His faceplate fogs up.  He clamps on an airhose.
They keep snapping apart.  Peter hurries down the corrido with no air, his breathing labored.
Probing the monkey.  Her gloves covered in blood.  Peter waves.  She doesn't see him.  He starts to pound the glass.  A warning sign stops him.
Air ROARS like a freight train.  She talks to herself.
(to herself)

Subcutaneous hemorrhaging. Patiechial lung hemorrhages.  Rapid tissue deterioration -- This thing's a bag of soup -- Suddenly her air stops flowing.  What?  She turns to chec the hose.  SHE FACES PETER:  her hose squeezed tightly in his gloves.  He lets go.  Air flows.
Hey -- what's up? He shoves the micrographs of Ebola up to her face plate. She takes them in her bloody gloves --
You've got crud in your scope. Peter indicates "no."  He's white as a ghost.
His air hose hangs loose.  Jaxx quickly clamps him onto a spare hose.  She gets in his face.  He's panicked --
It's Ebola!  I sniffed that flask!

Pete!  There's a good chance you're not infected!  Don't go dinki-dao on me now.  Antibodies.  Let's test them.  Get some "Sister G" serum -- She points to the big refrigerator with all the viruses. He nods, composing himself.

A monolith in the dim light.  Pete punches in the compute combination.  The titanium lock chungs.  THE DOOR OPENS. Nitrogen fog spills out. FOLLOW PETE'S GLOVE:  searching vials and containers marked:  LASSA, MARBURG, ANTHRAX, HANTA, RIFT VALLEY, ENCEPHALITIS, AIDS, EBOLA -- to one marked:  "ANTIBODY
Peter places the slide under the fluorescent microscope with forceps.  Jaxx presses her face plate to the scope -
Crawling with the Filovirus.  Antibodies seize on the cells lighting the cellscape in a foreboding purple glow.
These monkeys are loaded.  We've got to tell C.J. -- Peter freezes pointing at Jaxx's glove.
Jaxx holds her right glove up.  There's a huge hole between her thumb and forefinger.  She instantly reacts - JAMMING HER GLOVE in the Clorox washing it off.
Leaker -- oh shit --
Envirochem pounds her suit.  The system sign glows:
(humoring herself)
I can't die.  I don't have a baby- sitter.  Who'll feed my animals? Damn, I forgot to order the turkey for Thanksgiving.  I love Gerry --

Jaxx draws her right arm from the spacesuit glove.  Her inner surgical glove is covered in monkey blood too. Panic.  She pours more Clorox over the glove scrubbing it viciously with a brush trying to wash away the threat.

As she peels the glove slowly off.  She reaches the Band-aid -- no monkey blood.  Her hand is clean. Jaxx fills the glove up like a balloon at the faucet. Final verdict.  No leaks. Peter plops relieved; his suit dripping from the shower.
No leaks.  I'm fine.  No problem -- She heaves -- throwing up in the sink.
The Ebola Cellscape.
Shit.
C.J. sifts through the photos on the move.  Peter wears a surgical mask due to potential exposure.  Jaxx is wired -
That's not the Lochness Monster, C.J.  All seven primates were loaded.  That monkey house is a viral time bomb --
His door says it all:  COMMANDER ARMY MEDICAL RESEARCH. C.J., Jaxx and Peter barrel by the startled RECEPTIONIST.
Col. Peters, the General asked if this could wait until --
They enter.  GENERAL RUSSELL is getting ready to leave. C.J. shoves Pete's Ebola micrograph in front of him.
Shit. He looks back at Jaxx, Pete and C.J.  It's not.
A map of the world fills the view.  Colored pins mark locations of viral outbreaks.  JAXX ENTERS FRAME --
We've got a killer virus 25 miles from Washington D.C.
And five miles from the CIA.  Maybe this is no accident.  Maybe this is a new war.
Terrorism?  Bio-warfare?  Here? Jaxx points to the "hot spots" in Africa.

The only Ebola outbreak on record -- the '76 outbreak in Africa.  Now -- you can put a pin right here.  How? She points to the black pins in Africa and travels with her forefinger across the Atlantic.  She dramatically sticks a new BLACK PIN right next to Washington D.C.

Doesn't matter how the bug got here -- it's here.  If word gets out, we've got a major panic on our hands.  If the virus breaks out -- we've got an epidemic.  A disaster. Russell looks at the Cellscapes again in grim silence.
Pete, are we anywhere close to a vaccine for this bug? Peter meekly lowers his surgical mask.

I'm close on synthetic antibodies. But no proof it'll work on humans. The only antibody serum we've got is from Johnson's Nun.  And there's only enough of that to try and save one patient -- maybe. He replaces his mask.  Everyone speaks at once.
Everybody just slow down.  Millions of lives could be at stake.  It'd be nice if we had our shit together. Jaxx, C.J. and Peter grumble, duly admonished.
C.J., I'm putting you and Jaxx in charge of this operation.
We have to inform the CDC.  They're going to buck us for jurisdiction. This has to stay an Army operation. We need to get inside that monkey house as soon as possible before the bug gets outside --
Sir, there's a day care center right behind the primate house that should be closed immediately --

I appreciate your concern, Colonel, but if you do that, word'll get out and we'll have to close down the whole town.  I am not prepared to give that order. Jaxx bristles.  "Hurry up and wait" as usual.  She holds up the electron micrograph.
Then I'd like to fax these to Karl Johnson.  I want him in on the Epi- team controlling this thing. Instant shocked reactions from the men.  Peter pumps a fist -- "Yes" -- in support.
Karl?  That's a sure way to start a major-league panic.  He'll yell "fire" and scare the hell out of everybody.  Forget it.  He's retired.
The CDC and Karl Johnson in the same room is not a good idea.
He's big trouble, Jaxx.

With all due respect, Sir, we're already in trouble.  Johnson discovered Ebola and just about every other virus we're fighting. We need him. Peter agrees.  He drills C.J. in angry disbelief.  C.J. backs off -- getting angry with himself.
(self recrimination)
Karl taught me everything I know.  I should've called him myself.
(mischievous)
I already did.  Faxed him yesterday. Peter chuckles, digging at C.J.  Russell goes beet red. Jaxx prepares for the worst --
Damnit, Jaxx -- He fumes -- then slowly caves in.
Aw, what the hell -- If you can find him -- bring him in.  I'll call the CDC and tell Reese.  They'll sure piss in their pants.
Thank you -- Sir, Gentlemen -- guys. Jaxx is so pumped she's out the door.

C.J. -- call Girard.  Limit any contact his personal has with the monkeys.  Then get a hold of Virginia State Health, Interior, Agriculture -- find Col. Takafuji at the Surgeon General's office.  We'll have a "laydown" meet here as soon as possible so get your data in order. Russell grabs a phone -- man with a mission.
There's no doubt in my mind we've got a national emergency.  I don't want a panic.

head_text.subj: FOLLOW PETER AND C.J. OUT THE DOOR

text: "Panic?" Yeah, right.  He didn't sniff that flask.
(on phone)
Reese?  Phil.  Hey, we got a problem up here.  Found a little pissant filo virus in a bunch of monkeys down the road.  Ebola.  What d'ya think about that?
I think you've got crud in your scope.
Jaxx feeds the cellscape one by one into the machine.
C'mon, Johnson.  Where are you?

Jaxx's faxes scroll from the machine curling to an old plank floor.  Then another.  And another.  HANDS PICK up the streams of faxes and place them in a cardboard box. "JOHNSON" is scrawled on it in crayon.  WE CRANE UP THE SIDE OF THE BOX:  running over with uncollected faxes.
Johnson's fax box sits on the floor next to a sleeping Sheepdog.  An eclectic general store.  Everything from bait to NY bagels and gourmet wines -- Faxes keep coming.

A neon "FAX" sign hangs in the dirty window.  WIDEN TO: bigger sign the reads:  "Auto Repairs - Video Rentals - Gourmet Wines - Stock Feed - Outfitters - UPS - Fedex - Xerox Copies." SUPER: THURSDAY, NOV. 18 - BIG SKY, MONTANA - 0900 HRS.
Taking in the eclectic sight.  She gets out and heads in.
Jaxx exits toting the faxbox, a bundle of mail, some fishing tackle and two-fifths of Dewars Scotch.
As far as we can see.  Snow capped peaks.  PAN DOWN TO:
KARL JOHNSON - HIS BACK TO US:  stands waist-deep in the middle of the river.  Still in his favorite fishing hat, he rips his line off the water and lays a cast upstream.
Dr. Johnson?!
Tentative.  She yells again over the roaring rapids.
Karl Johnson?!!
He turns to us, surprised.  He's twelve years older.  His features elegantly weathered over the decades.  He studie Jaxx with those piercing eyes -- like a Bear sizing her up.
I'm Nancy Jaxx.  Remember? -- I was a PFC in the Medical Corps your last year at "RIID." He clearly doesn't recognize her.  He gets a strike upstream.  Bad timing for Jaxx.
You trained me with the first Airborne medical isolator team. He shrugs annoyed walking upstream reeling in his fish.
There was a women in the A.I.T. unit?  And I don't remember?
(ego bruised)
I was the only woman in that unit. Now I'm in Special Pathogens.
(testy)
Yeah?  So was I.  Now, I'm retired. Can't you see I'm fishing?!
C.J. Peters sent me!  I have to talk to you about Ebola! Johnson reacts even more annoyed.  He nets his fish.
I don't do any lectures until the spring.  Contact me then -- He looks his prize brown trout in the eye and lets it go.
Jaxx watches the fish swim away -- Then she watches the man who set it free.  There is a nobility about him as he makes his way upstream to his Drifter Boat resting on the shore.
Johnson stows his gear and starts to shove off.  Jaxx climbs in.  Johnson thinks she's nuts.

Look -- I flew all night in a military transport to get here.  And I heard your "Emerging Viruses" talk at the Trop-med conference two years ago -- in case you don't remember. It was -- fascinating.  See how this makes you feel? She pulls a folder from her daypack and shoves it to him. Johnson eyes her warily as he opens it.  He stares at --
Old ghosts haunt him.  PUSH IN ON JOHNSON'S EYES:  Fixed on the image.  SOUNDS OF AFRICA surround him.
Unless you include the feeling generated by gazing into the eyes of a cobra, "fascination" is not what I feel about Ebola. (looks right at Jaxx)
How about 'Shit scared'? Johnson abruptly casts off.  Jaxx almost falls in.
Through the rapids.  Jaxx whoops hanging on.
There's never been a case of Ebola isolated on this continent!  How in the hell did it get to Virginia?! He guides the Drifter expertly up a swell and crashes dow into a chute.  Jaxx yells again.
That's why I came to find you!
Johnson and Jaxx pull the Drifter ashore in the calm of a backwater.  His Cabin is visible set back in the trees.
He's pumped annoyed and angry all in the same moment.  Th world has intruded on him here in paradise.
What about exposure?  Anybody died yet?  Anybody spiked fever?
Just the monkeys.  And one exposure at our lab so far. He stops Jaxx in her tracks -- getting right in her face --

You don't know that for sure -- do you?  Do you?  You don't know how many people this bug could be incubating in do you?  And I'll bet my hat the CDC doesn't know either. She doesn't.  He doesn't wait for an answer.  He stalks on.

I warned them this would happen. They didn't see what I saw in Africa.  As long as these viruses are killing black people and yellow people and red and brown in far off places -- why should we give a big woolly damn here at home?

He bumps the door open and enters.  Jaxx hesitates, bristling, pumping herself up, she follows him inside. It's an eclectic collection of fishing gear, Indian art, African and South American artifacts, carvings, photos --
Dr. Johnson, I think you should know the Ebola vaccine has been a priority at RIID --
And you haven't got one yet, do you? Do you? Jaxx shakes her head "no" guiltily.
Do you know where Ebola comes from? Huh?  The natural host?  The reservoir?  After all these years? -- Take a wild guess -- Jaxx angrily shakes "no."  He opens the Dewars --

Don't say monkeys.  The Virus kills them too quick for a monk to be a host.  Twelve years and we still don't know what animal, vegetable, mineral or insect Ebola comes from. -- fishing a glass from a shelf, he fills it and knocks i back.  No sympathy from Jaxx.
So what are you hiding out here for? He shoots her a lethal look.
Okay, "fishing."  I mean -- why did you retire?  Quit your research? He pours another and one for her.  His voice calms.
Why?  Because nobody really wants to cure these diseases.  The Bureaucrats and Doctors would rather fight over who gets credit -- and who patents the cure. (hands her a drink)
The world's got a gun to it's head and there's nothing I can do to keep it from pulling the trigger. It absolutely predestined truth the way Karl says it. Jaxx heard Peter say it.  She heard enough.

-- You don't remember me, but I remember this about you -- I heard you say the best place to be in an outbreak is at the epicenter... trying anything possible to stop it -- I guess I was mis-informed... She returns the full glass, completely disillusioned.
Go... fishing. She shakes perfunctorily and heads for the door.  Johnson watches her go with profound regret.
Hey -- Jaxx.  We found another virus in a lot of the blood samples we took in Zaire.  AIDS. Jaxx stops.  Chilled.
We had AIDS samples back in '76?
Yeah.  But it wasn't killing anyone. Ebola was. He chokes it off.  Pain and sorrow in his eyes.

We could've been ready for AIDS.  We could've saved some lives. Jaxx stares at him in stunned silence, reeled by the ramifications.  She has a better understanding of this man's pain -- and a deeper respect.
Everyone knows "it's not nice to fool with Motha Nate-cha." Now she's got us by the -- He gestures squeezing with a cupped hand -- He cuts himself off, suddenly an embarrassed gentleman --

"Balls," Karl.  She's got us by the balls. Their eyes meet.  She's pried him loose.  He's ready.  He offers her the full scotch glass.  She clinks it against his.  They knock the Scotches back.  Warriors going to war.
The CAMERA GLIDES THROUGH:  THIRTY FIVE CIVILIANS AND MILITARY PERSONNEL caucusing and buzzing with the mission

It's not a recon photo -- but the Ebola cellscape. A WAR MAP fills another screen.  It's of Washington D.C. and vicinity.  A series of expanding circles fan out from Reston, Virginia right over Washington D.C. GENERAL RUSSELL makes his point to a small group includin COL. TAKAFUJI of the Surgeon General's and an ASSISTANT from the Dept. of Interior.
If we have a respiratory threat -- and it gets loose -- up to ten million people could be exposed.
Coffeed out and hot tempered, makes his point to GIRARD and some SUITS from Synergy along with CDC REPS.

This virus could jump and start burning through the human population right now.  Today.  We've got to get in there and depopulate the entire primate colony before that happens. Instant reaction.  All focus turns to C.J.'s group.
What about my company's investment? Not all the monkeys have symptoms. I'm not going to euthanize perfectly healthy specimens --
The Army will handle the operation. C.J. is about to blow.  A familiar voice speaks up.

The Army's done a great job -- CHUCK REESE separates the Army and Girard's contingent. Chuck hasn't changed much since that day 12 years ago wit Johnson in Africa.  Now in his late 30's, he's risen to the top of the heap at CDC.

-- up to now.  And everyone at CDC is really grateful, C.J., to your team for sounding the alarm.  We'll take over from here.  So if you'll give us virus samples and your data -- C.J. bristles at Reese's tone.  No love lost here.
Chuck, that sounds a little like "give the big boys the sharp objects before we hurt ourselves."  Synergy called in the Army and we will maintain our alert status.
C.J. -- c'mon.  We don't need to start a war here. Battle lines drawn.  The room buzzes.

I was in Africa with Karl Johnson during the Zaire event.  I worked in close contact with Ebola victims at Kinshasa for two months and was never infected. Reese grabs Peter's micrographs waving them around.
There was no data in Africa to support aerosol transmission -- We don't even know if it's the same strain. C.J. and the USAMRIID team argue in disarray.
I recommend we low-key the press and media.  We can't afford to "cry wolf" to the American public -- A commotion at the back of the room disrupts everyone --
You can't afford not to --
A major stir.  Raised eyebrows and confusion around. Johnson's name ripples through the room. Karl shakes C.J.'s hand as he dumps his bag on the table.
Sorry I'm late -- C.J. glares at Jaxx -- then nods a private "thank you." Jaxx lets out a huge sigh of relief.
Karl -- glad you're here. Gen. Russell shakes his head waiting for the fireworks. Reese looks like a deer caught in the headlights.
Dr. Johnson -- Karl, we were just wrapping up --
Well, I'm just beginning --
Like Merlin and Clarence Darrow merged.

Monkeys, separated in cages with no social contact, are dying days and weeks apart from the first outbreak. That indicates a strong airborne transmission threat -- He illustrates the transmission pattern on a standup diagram of the monkey house.
Do you, all of you, want to take the chance with innocent people? He fixes on Girard who can't hold his piercing gaze.

You have to quarantine the Monkey Handlers and anyone who had unprotected contact -- NOW.  They could be exposed and incubating. You have to put a surveillance plan into action to watch their families and co-workers for symptoms -- Lots of reaction here.  Jaxx is mesmerized watching Karl ignite the room.  Girard has had it --
Is this man in charge here? General Russell pulls C.J. aside --
You better control him, C.J. C.J. just grins and nods, loving every minute of this. Reese jockeys for the floor.
Look, we don't know if the virus can jump species from monkeys to people. Nobody's sick.  Right? Girard nods confirming this fact.  Reese scores points --
The monkeys with Ebola are going to die anyway.  We'll harvest the infected ones and save the rest. Girard and the Synergy contigent audibly approve.  The power has shifted visibly in the room.
Karl -- I think you're overreacting -- Wrong thing to say.   Karl drills Reese with his eyes --

I am...?  It only takes seven days to find out once you've got it. First come the headaches -- followed by a relentless fever.  Then the hemorrhaging begins.  Your skin goes pulpy and tears easily.  It speckles with petechiae -- erupts is a rash that turns your flesh to tapioca pudding.  Your bowels fill up completely with blood.  So do your eyeballs.  You vomit a thick black fluid -- After bloody diarrhea, you pass your intestines, what's left of them --
Disgust, horror, fear.  One Man leaves the room nauseated
A man's testicles swell up the size of footballs.  And if you're not dead by then or comatose, you've become hostile -- acute psychosis -- dementia -- A Preacher's pause...
At the end, you're leaking blood and huge quantities of virus from the nose, mouth, anus, eyes, nipples -- rips in the skin... -- letting the images sink in.

The black plague killed four out of ten people.  When the white man and the red man exchanged diseases, seven out of ten died.  Ebola wipes the slate -- nine out of ten people in this room won't be here. He turns, making eye contact with everyone in the room.
You have no choice -- but to cry wolf. ... Dead fucking silence.
Peter draws his own blood with a syringe.
He places his blood slide under the microscope and studie it on the monitor.  He sits back relieved.  He swivels in his stool to a wall calendar.
He marks another day off in red.  Two down, five to go to the day he's marked "E-DAY"... Thanksgiving.
Anybody home? His voice vibrates through thin diaphragms set in the thick glass enabling communication into the suite. Peter walks to the glass happy to see his old mentor.
Just us flesheaters. Karl gets a good look at Peter close to the glass.  Guine Pigs fill the wall behind him.  His followers.
I heard about your little flask sniffing episode.  How're you doing? Peter looks at the non-existent watch on his suit wrist.

Let's see, I was exposed two days ago.  Incubation takes about a week; therefore.  If I'm infected, I should be getting my first headaches in, oh, about five days.  If I spike a fever, seven days later -- the guys around here will be flipping coins to see who gets my vacation days -- Karl doesn't laugh.  Peter sobers under his stern eye.
If the bug spreads by aerosol, you won't be the only one with a headache. Peter shys, almost sheepish.
Actually, I've been sleeping here -- in the lab.  I don't want to expose my family... Karl is impressed by his protege's discipline.
You know you're not contagious unless you have symptoms, Pete. Don't woof me.  How's your blood?
(crossing his gloved fingers)

No Ebola antibodies yet.  The test tube-witch willing -- I can go home for Thanksgiving. He points to:  THE CALENDAR:  THANKSGIVING; five more days.  Peter smiles hopefully.  Karl sees the fear in his eyes.

Reese still doesn't believe the bug's airborne.  All that red tape must've choked off the air supply to his brain. Peter pushes his glasses back up on his nose through his plastic visor -- he motions Karl inside.
Crawling with the virus.  Armies of it.  A huge Ebola brick shaped like a shark fills the view.
Monkey snot -- Look at that big honker.  Definite airborne threat.
Karl peers at the monitor scope wearing surgical mask, visor, gloves and scrubs.  He sits back depressed.
I hate being right sometimes.  The monkey house is not the end.  It's the beginning. He muses -- eyes fixed on some other horizon.
How are you fixed for Sister Genevieve?

Gold plated stuff.  Her immuno plasma is still the strongest therapy we've got against Ebola... At least in my guinea pigs. Peter reverently holds up a packet of plasma to the glass marked "Sister G."  Johnson savors it.  A long lost friend.
Sister "G"... she beats Ebola -- She beats it -- then dies of AIDS three years later she picked up in the same hospital... Hell, nobody said life was fair.
We're down to less than four units.
That's not quite enough to fight an epidemic.

If Sister "G" was alive, I could clone her immune cells for my synthetic antibody trials.  We could crank out anti-ebola serum like a Chinese noodle factory.  We could immunize our troops -- dogs -- cats -- even politicians -- The two men share a moment of hopeful laughter.
C'mon.  Let's blow this fishtank. Beer and Pulitzer Pizza on me. Peter doesn't move.  He shakes his head reluctantly "no."
You're a good virologist, Pete. Karl puts his gloved hand on the glass by Peter's.
This funny little man in a blue spacesuit smiles shyly from the BL4 lab window like a big lonely blue fish.

Gerry checks the leg cast on a BIRDDOG.  Blackhawk snooze at his feet.  Suddenly the Big Bouvier is up -- alert -- JAXX ENTERS from the house carrying a couple of beers still in her traveling clothes.  Ever up.  Tireless.
Room service. She hugs Gerry from behind rocking to and fro.
I'll give you about an hour to stop that -- She plops beside him and pops the beers.
How's the legendary Dr. Johnson? Still the "ladies man"?
I wouldn't kick him out of bed. She's pricking him.  Gerry punches her half-jealous.
So?  You're going to nuke the monkey house?
No.  Just one room.  About a hundred "cynos."  Synergy's stonewalling. They're still arguing.  CDC is low keying the whole thing to "John Q." Gerry whistles his disapproval.
C.J. put me in charge of the monkey operation.  I'm looking for "a few good men -- AND women."
What about Army S.W.A.T.?
They won't touch it.
What about Special Forces?
They won't touch it.

Colonel, Jaxx, you don't need the Green Berets.  I've got more military experience handling diseased animals than even anybody at RIID.  I'm your first volunteer. Gerry takes her in his arms.  She breaks off troubled.
I've seen this look on you before. This is the "our daughter needs a training bra stare."  You're worried about the kids?
They're growing up so fast.  I was thinking -- if anything happens... to either of us, I'd feel better if the kids where someplace safe...
We can send them down to my folks for an early holiday... So they miss a couple of days of school before Thanksgiving.  They won't mind -- Gerry holds her to him.  She gets a chill.
This is "closehold" info.  We can't even tell Jason and Jamie why.
Gerry loads the kid's duffels in his pickup.  Jaxx says goodbye to Jamie.  Jason hangs back.
Mom?  What's going on?
Don't worry, Hon.  We're going to be real busy at the lab and -- Jamie instantly goes on the offensive.
-- and you just don't want me around when you off a bunch of defenseless guinea pigs.  Right? Jamie pulls away from their embrace.
Jamie -- I'll explain it all --
(not interested)
Dad got out of the army.  Why can't you? Silence.  Jamie climbs in and slams the door glaring at her mother through the windshield. Jaxx puts on a braveface --
See you Thanksgiving.  Tell Popsy and Mama to bring their appetites. Love you... -- watching them leave.  Blackhawk barks them away.

A pastoral farm.  Sheep and Goats graze.  Several horses roam the corral.  The oddity is the ARMY MEN AND WOMEN assembled at the barn in camouflage fatigues.  Officially they are classified as "91 Tango Animal Handlers."  The Veterinarians Corps.  Jaxx addresses them.
The General Public pretty much believes we're into biological warfare and torturing animals for research -- I know my daughter does -- Laughter ripples.
We know our mission is to save human lives on the battlefield -- Most are in their "teens."  Klages is there with SGT. PIERRA, her boyfriend.  Godwin holds a baby goat feeding it milk from a bottle.

Now we have a chance to do just that right where we live.  This operation involves a high degree of risk. You'll be working in a densely populated area under close quarters to euthanize diseased animals infected with a rare and most deadly pathogen. Grave faces stare back at her.  She tries to lighten up.

Hey -- the Green Berets passed. Fighting viruses doesn't suit their image, they say.  The Navy Seals chickened out.  You're 91 Tango Animal Care Specialists!  You're better trained for this operation than any branch of the military! Big reaction from the young group.  Klages and her Boyfriend lead the whoop.

This is on a volunteer basis.  I can't tell you how important our success is to the safety of thousands of innocent people. This brings everyone down to earth.  Klages squeezes her Boyfriend's hand and steps forward.
I'd like to help, Colonel. Jaxx nods.  Klages is only a few years older than Jamie. Immediately her boyfriend "volunteers" too.  Then another
Thank you.  This is closehold info. We don't want a panic before the operation.  No discussion with family or friends.  Am I clear? Godwin pipes up with her goat.
Colonel, Jaxx, M'am.  My folks had to sign a waiver for me to get in the Army.  I'm still 17.  I don't want to miss this -- Jaxx beams with pride at the bravery of these kids.
I'd be proud to have you, Pvt. Godwin.  But you need a note from your mother. Laughter.  Godwin is embarrassed.  Jaxx gives her a Mom hug.
Jaxx spots Johnson feeding a big Clydesdale.  She enters.
Well, we have the first bio-hazard team in U.S. history --
Doesn't matter what kind of war it is -- we still send kids to do the fighting.
I sent mine to Grandma's house. Johnson grins, then sees Jaxx isn't trying to be funny. Silence.  He handfeeds more oats to the horse.
We're looking at one of life's true mysteries. Jaxx eyes him, puzzled.  He leads the horse out.
Ebola won't even make this horse even a little sick, a dumb animal. But the same bug can wipe out the most intelligent species on Earth.
Makes you wonder who's the smarter species -- Us or Them... Johnson turns the horse loose.  It bolts into the pasture Jaxx looks at him long and hard.
You find the viruses beautiful, don't you... It's not a question.  It's her scientific observation.
(softly, gently)
Oh yeah.  Looking at Ebola under an electron microscope is like looking at a gorgeously wrought ice castle. The thing is so cold.  So totally pure.
The upper Potomac gleams before the Appalachians.
These viruses have been on Earth a long, long time.  Along comes the human invasion.  Too many people violating the habitat. He picks up a handful of hay to illustrate --

We clear a forest, the virus comes out.  It doesn't "emerge."  We crash right into the bugs.  Bam. Epidemic.  Our population gets thinned out.  This is nature. -- tossing strands away until the last straw remains.
Wiping us out?  It can't get that far -- can it?
Nobody's safe from this bug, Nancy. None of us -- Jaxx reaches out taking the last straw.

head_text.subj: ANYONE ENTERING ANIMAL ROOMS MUST HAVE
DEAD ANIMALS ARE TO BE DOUBLE BAGGED AND

text: WIDEN TO:  TINY; reading the notice in the maintenance room.  His eyes are red.  He's sweating.  Deke, the handler who looks like a Biker, is panicked.
What's all this 'sposed t'mean -- ? Tiny wipes his forehead.  He's spooked but hides it.
Ah, just "monkey flu," prob'ly.

The room is jammed with HANDLERS and LAB WORKERS. Two EIS OFFICERS in white military style uniforms sit at the desks interviewing People one by one and taking blood samples.  TINY is next in line before Deke. GIRARD ROAMS uneasily.  Everyone in the room looks uneasy REESE fields questions.  A BLACK WOMAN cuts him off --
I don't care what happened in Africa.  I wanna know if I'm gonna get sick working here and maybe die 'fore my children get home from school -- This is not the "low key" meeting Reese had hoped for.
Please just be calm.  One of the Epidemic Investigators will take care of you. (points to EIS officers)
Your bloodtests are confidential. If you have any of the symptoms -- call us immediately.

head_text.subj: THE VIEW ROCKETS IN ON TINY

text: He watches his blood rise in the vial from the needle in his arm.  Squeamish -- sweat rivulets run down his nose.
All angles.  silent.  Waiting.
Jaxx feeds her menagerie.  This could be the last time. Maggie, the old bulldog, manages to wake up for a big fac lick.  Her Parrots wolf whistle.
(ritual)
Thanks, guys.  Eat your heart out girls. Blackhawk jumps up for a hug, almost refusing to let her go as if the dog knows there is danger ahead. Gerry enters, duffel bag in hand.  It's time.
PVT. KLAGES exits in her civvies and gets in a waiting car driven by her boyfriend, SGT. PIERRA.  They drive on.
PVT. GODWIN talks on the phone to her mother.
(on phone)
Everything's fine, Mom, really.  I have to go, Mom.  Love you, too.
Peter checks his blood under the scope.  He "high-fives" air -- marking another day on his calendar.  "Three to go." He does some jumping jacks to rev himself up.
Bitter cold.  Overcast.  EIGHT ARMY MEMBERS load the thre white UNMARKED VANS with anesthesia/euthanasia gear, ice chests for samples, etc.  All wear civvies.

Action report, Col. Nancy Jaxx. November 20th.  Assembled Team at Post, 0630.  Civilian clothes for drive to Reston to avoid attention -- JOHNSON pitches in with JAXX and GERRY loading gear. A 4 Man AIRBORNE MEDICAL ISOLATOR TEAM load an isolator stretcher -- hermetically sealed with its own air supply. Orange spacesuits with bubble helmets are stacked on top.
No personnel with experience in Racal spacesuits except me; I've asked the Airborne Medical Isolator Team to give technical support --
Sit in back "shucking" syringes; i.e. removing the wrappers from syringes and loading them with anesthetic.
Mood tense... Anticipation high... They eye the stretcher warily as it's loaded.  Casualties
A few PEOPLE are going to work in other buildings.  GIRAR PARKS in front of Synergy.
Deke, the handler, is standing on the lawn wearing a respirator, gloves and heavy jumpsuit. Girard gets out furious.
What are you doing outside?  People can see -- Deke suddenly raises his respirator, drops to his knees and vomits.  Girard recoils.  "Scared shitless."
The White Vans creep in rush hour traffic.
Johnson smokes anxiously reading the Washington Post.  We see the inside headline:  "Deadly Ebola Virus Found in Va Laboratory Monkey:  Animals Sent to U.S. from Philippines."
(reading; cringing with the words)
"This virus does not spread that easily," said CDC expert Chuck Reese, "There's a low probability of someone getting infected."
The traffic stretches to the Potomac.  The Washington Monument and Capitol hill gleam white in the morning sun.
-- And V.P., Dan Quayle said to reporters President Bush is not breaking his "read my lips" promise. It's Congress who's forcing him to ask for new taxes --
LOCAL NEWS plays on three TVs.  C.J. covers his phone, signaling a Deputy C.O.
It's Girard.  They've got a man down.  Get Reese -- and Johnson.
PARAMEDICS carry Deke out on a litter.  Girard is scared.
(on phone)
He's got symptoms.  I'm evacuating the building and... I'm officially requesting the Army to destroy all the monkeys... Sterilize the whole facility...
(on phone)
I'll need that in writing.  The Team's already enroute.
It's from Girard.  C.J. reads it.  The "go ahead."
Karl hangs up the mobile phone.  He's pumped.
The good news is we're nuking the whole colony.  The bad news is the virus just jumped species.  A Handler went to the hospital with symptoms.  It'll be all over the six o'clock news.
The RESTON exit sign rushes toward them.
The Vans deploy on the grass behind the building.  Girard waits at the Maintenance door with the 2 EIS Officers.

Gerry and the rest of the Team watch from the Vans as Girard and Jaxx speak inaudibly.  He hands her the keys t the building and the signed release.  He practically runs to his car -- he can't wait to get out of there. The EIS Officers head inside.  Jaxx signals.
AIT PERSONNEL pile out and carry equipment inside.
Tell everyone to hit the head.  Once they suit up the only place to go is down your leg. MAJ. HAINES, the AIT leader, cracks up.  Tension released

Gerry throws sheets of plastic over a rope dividing the back of the van into a crude changing room. THE NEAR SIDE:  Gerry and Sgt. Pierra strip naked. Shivering in the cold, they jerk on surgical scrubs. THE FAR SIDE:  Klages and Godwin laugh embarrassed. Klages starts shucking clothes.  Then Godwin.  Both freezing cold.
Jaxx joins him.  The sound of children echoes in the air.
Nice neighborhood.  Kids.  Fast food.  Diseased monkeys.  Good city planning.
The playground and happy children.  Jaxx purges her guilt
We're carrying out this o.p. next to children -- We should've told them -- We should've evacuated them.
Why didn't you?
Orders.  Might start a panic.  I'd pick panic over an epidemic anyday.

The storeroom is crowded.  The AIT's help Klages, Godwin, Sgt. Pierra, Maj. Haines, Lt. Rice, Gerry Jaxx and Johnson into the orange lightweight RACAL spacesuits and plastic bubble helmets.  The EIS officers observe. NOTE:  This process requires one person act as "dresser" -- like putting armor on a Knight.  Brown sticky tape is applied to all seams and zippers.  Suiting up continues throughout this scene.
Shivering in her scrubs.  She lays down sticking her legs up.  The AIT leader spreads her suit legs.  She pulls the on.  She briefs as she suits up.  This like a cadence.

I know they look like "K-Mart specials," but the Racals will protect you in BL4 conditions. Once again she evokes some nervous laughter releasing tension.  She straps her battery pack blower on her back.
You've got six hours on the air pump battery.  So decon out before it fails or you're in trouble. She holds up a roll of sticky tape --
These suits are fragile.  Monkey claws and fangs'll slice them like butter -- If you get a rip -- She easy rips a rend in her leg spooking everyone.

-- tape it shut fast or contaminated air can flow inside.  I keep extra tape around my legs just in case. She tapes the rend shut.  Gerry checks the seal.  GODWIN AND KLAGES look at each other.  "What've we done?"
Be exquisitely careful.  Stick with your buddy.  Watch for rips in each other's suits. She pulls on her gloves and tapes the wrists.

Know where your hands are at all times.  If you get blood on you, stop and clean it off.  With bloody gloves, you can't see holes in them. Believe me, I know from experience... Gerry? Gerry holds up a syringe --

Never hand a used needle to your buddy.  If a needle comes out of its cap, it goes straight into an animal -- He fixes the syringe on the end of a special pole with a syringe clamp on the end.  A deadly spear.
Don't recap it.  You could stick yourself.  Bag it. He removes the syringe and drops it in a disposable bag.
Everyone decons out to the cold side for a fifteen minute break every two hours.  If you get tired, or sick -- tell your supervisor.

Godwin, Maj. Haines, Lt. Rice, Maj. Powell, Gerry Jaxx an Karl Johnson.  One by one, the AIT Team fit clear bubble helmets over their heads and tie them in place. Klages' suit pressurizes making her look fat.  Nervous giggles.  Lots of sweat.  All excited and scared.
Karl... Anything to add...? Johnson takes a moment, then --

We're going to euthanize a whole building full of animals as humanely as possible.  Remember, they're sick and dying.  They were caught up in this... It's not their fault. Faces in helmets.  Grimset.  Scared.  Air blowers kick on one by one.  FM headsets activate.
Don't forget for a second -- they carry the most deadly virus known. Let's go.  We'll go in by twos -- The Team grabs up gear and line up like paratroopers -- Gerry presses his helmet to Jaxx's.
How am I supposed to kiss you good- bye, Colonel?

We're on the air, Ger.  Watch your "six." She points behind him.  The Team is smiling at them. Jaxx presses her helmet to her lips with her pointer finger then presses it to him.  Their eyes say it all.
Push in on the Red Trefoil Biohazard symbol until it fill the view --
The staging area door opens slowly.  Light spills into th long dark hallway leading to the holding rooms.
Step into the "gray zone."  The air is heavy.  Dense.  No sounds from the monkeys.  Gerry instantly pours sweat. Their helmets fog up --
Damnit -- can't see.  It's burning up in here.  Must be 90 degrees --
Thermostat?  Let's find it. They head into the musky corridor.  Fluorescent lights glow that "end-of-the-world-red" in the heavy musky air.
One breath and she LEADS THE TEAM in by twos. KLAGES AND GODWIN pause at the door.  WE HEAR:  their breathing, the rush of air, their heartbeats.  They squeeze each other's hands, and enter --
Fogged helmets.  Air pump rushing.  Poor vision.  They turn the corner at the cage washing area --

head_text.subj: FACE TO FACE WITH TWO MEN --

text: Coming right at them.  The Handlers look at each other. They're in jeans and t-shirts.  What the hell is going on
What the hell are you doing here?! This is a hot zone -- Loc, the Vietnamese, points to the dismantled thermostat and speaks rapidly in his language.  Johnson understands.
(in Vietnamese)
He doesn't mean "heat" -- "death." "Killing field."  Leave now. They escort the two frightened Men away.
The two frightened men enter.  Gerry slams the door behin them.  The two EIS officers on duty look up surprised.

QUICK CUTS:  KLAGES AND GODWIN lay out necropsy tools on bleed table; scalpels, cutters, lancets, pipettes, blood syringes -- the "sharps." PIERRA sets out rows of "kill syringes."  RICE stacks plastic bags and biohazard body boxes.

They pause at the door to Room "F."  Karl carries a mop handle with a "U-shaped" prong on the end to hold the monkey.  Jaxx carries the pole and a bag of syringes.  Sh signals down the hall to: GERRY AND MAJ. HAINES; Ready at Door "H."  Gerry counts three -- they enter.
Johnson pushes open the door with his broom handle.  It's dark.  Visibility poor.  Instantly MONKEYS screech and rattle about.  An unnerving cacophony in the gloom.
Cynos haven't been fed.  They're freaked -- Hunger gets them hostile.

head_text.subj: MONKEY EYES STARING AT US. NOSES BLEEDING. FANGS
FLASHING. PAWS CLAWING AT US THROUGH THE BARS.

text: TO JOHNSON:  Sounds of Africa surround him.  He blinks.
Faces of the dead.  Burning huts.  The big Male standing four feet tall on his hood screeching at him --
Screeching from its cage.  Karl jerks back breathing hard JAXX APPEARS beside him.
Karl?  Karl!  You okay? He nods, his heart pounding.

Moving from cage to cage with precision and rhythm; HAINE PINS a monkey with the mop handle O.S., GERRY THRUSTS his pole syringe in the cage injecting the animal O.S.  Gerry dumps the used syringe and loads another.  They move like a martial arts kata.
Children play enjoying the day.
People come and go at the McDonalds across the street. Down the block at the Amoco Station, more mundane life. The Grocery store advertises "Butterball Turkeys."
Deke lays sedated in an oxygen tent.  Reese is there with TWO HOSPITAL OFFICIALS and MEDICAL STAFF who are nervous.

Full barrier gear; scrubs, gloves, masks must be worn.  I don't want any other patients on this floor until we do the bloodwork and find out if he's really contracted the virus. C.J. pulls him aside.  The Doctors talk uneasily O.S.
Let's get him back to the post.  Our medical slammer has BL4 isolation. Our med-staff are trained for this --
We'll contain it here.  Protecting the public from infectious diseases is our jurisdiction.  Don't make a scene, C.J., please --
A scene?  This guy's bloodwork was done here in their lab.  If it's lethal with virus and contamination occurs, this hospital will go up like wildfire. Reese escorts C.J. politely from the room.

Klages bags liver and spleen samples and puts them in a cooler full of organs.  Her gloves are covered in blood. She washes the bloody table with Clorox then places another monkey down.  She picks up a swab and takes a nos sample, flips it, takes another --

Drawing blood from a sedated monkey.  (Only syringe and part of monkey hindquarter visible).  As blood fills the tube; TILT UP TO:  GODWIN singing softly to the monkey, like mother to child -- Eric Clapton's "Tears in Heaven." As she places the blood vial in a box filled with blood samples, we see she is crying.
He fumbles for a scalpel with his gloves. He slits the top from a cadaver bag and peers in.  (We don't see what he sees).  His breathing is rapid.
Can't breath in here. Klages turns to him.  Checking him out --
You okay?
Sweat rivulets run down his forehead into his eyes.  His faceplate fogs up.  He wipes instinctively with his glove smearing the visor on his wet face making it worse.
Get me outta this fuckin' thing!
He wipes his faceplate violently with his glove.  The scalpel in his hand slices the clear plastic bubble open. Air rushes out.  He goes nuts --

Aw, fuck!  I'm leaking!  Oh shit! KLAGES FORCES the scalpel from his hand.  He flails, knocking over the tray of sharps.  His airhose uncouples. GERRY ENTERS the Gray Zone on the double.  He grabs Pierr from behind pinning his arms back.

head_text.subj: KLAGES GETS RIGHT IN HIS FACE

text: Sergeant!  Look at me! Pierra does -- military reflex.  Klages, in control, rips a piece of brown sticky tape from a roll on her sleeve -- and tapes shut the tear in his faceplate. Gerry rehooks his hose.  Air rushes in.  His suit holds it.
You're Okay!  You're not losing air pressure. Pierra instantly calms.  He smiles sheepishly at Klages -
Thanks... buddy... -- and faints on the floor in his clumsy suit.
Gerry and Klages help Pierra through the door.  Rice and Haines instantly hose the trio down with disinfectant. Gerry is exhausted.  He's white as a ghost.  And aged --
Thanks, Mr. Jaxx -- you look -- older --
(meeting her gaze)
I thought I just felt that way. (looks around concerned)
Where's Nancy?  Has she taken a break yet?  Johnson? Klages indicates "no."
Jaxx crawls into frame on her hands and knees.  She loads another pole syringe and peers into the next cage.  She vapor locks -- staring at a very scary sight.
We've got a loose one! She stands up peering around the dank dark room.  It coul be anywhere.  KARL POPS UP on the other side of the row scaring the shit out of her --
Aw -- Jesus Christ --
I don't think so -- !  Where'd it go? He fumbles his flashlight on checking the lower cages.
Just keep looking -- Something rattles in the corner.  They wheel.  Nothing. Johnson's air blower suddenly stops.  His suit begins to deflate.  He turns to Jaxx --
Nancyyyy -- She spanks his battery pack.  It sputters to life.  He smiles in relief.  It dies again.
It's dead.  Get out of here.
I'm not leaving you.  I've got two minutes air in the suit --
A shadowy figure moves impossibly along the ceiling right above them.  Sitting ducks.
His flashlight fans the heavy air checking the room. Sedated monkeys in their cages.  Suddenly the dim light from overhead begins to sway --
A fierce Green perches on the sprinkler pipes like a gargoyle -- hissing at the humans.  Gnashing fangs, blood running from it's eyes and nose.
Oh shit, I do not like this --
It leaps SHRIEKING.  Right at us.  Eyes bulging wild.

head_text.subj: JOHNSON PULLS HER TO THE DECK --
THE MONKEY SLAMS INTO THE CAGES --

text: Swinging wildly from one to another.
Chasing it along the wall --
We've got a loose one in "K." Somebody bring a net!
She lost it.  She turns.  The 4 foot tall thing SPRINGS A HER from the floor.

Lunging, snapping at her.  Jaxx grabs it's arms and legs blocking it's attack.  The infected monkey has become a primordial beast, "raptor-like," a killing machine. JOHNSON POKES it with his mop handle.  The thing sinks it fangs into the handle and won't let go -- Johnson SLINGS the monkey -- THROUGH THE AIR --
The monkey burst out the door sliding on the floor.  It takes off running. Jaxx and Johnson shove out of Room K giving chase.
We got a contagious cyno headed for the Gray Zone!
